First off, happy anniversary.
10 years is nothing to scoff at.

My name is Professor

entrepreneurship and finance

Harvard Business School.

And I've been lucky enough
to work with the MENA Center
on a number of my cases.

And today, I want to talk
a little bit about one

of my favorite cases on family
enterprises and family offices.
And that's on the Alagil family.

Here's why I like
that case so much.

This case has turned
out to really form

one of the cornerstones of the
course I teach because it deals

with a fundamental problem
that every family faces,

which is as our family grows
and we get lucky enough

to see that growth and
be a part of that growth,

how do we both keep
the family close

but allow them to go off
and do the amazing things we
want them to do?

And the Alagils
have a great formula

for doing that that I share
with families around the world

and that, frankly, families
write me about as one

of the most effective both
rules and implementations

that they put in
within their families.

And this is to allow both a
springboard for the outside

but also create a magnet
that keeps family excited

and keeps them close to
the family enterprise.

So let me tell you a little bit
about how this case came to be

and working with the MENA
Center because I know
I don't have too much time.

So I started to work with
the MENA Center on this case,

and I have to say, I couldn't

Every interview we

to unravel more and more that

And just the more I

and really wanted to be a part

And so, in fact, this one case

I believe it's
important to feature

untold stories
about entrepreneurs
who are from the Middle East.

There are many success stories
about entrepreneurs from Jordan

in particular, and
the Hikma story

is a great one that
is worthy of being
featured in the HBS classroom.

Students most
definitely will benefit

from studying cases of diverse
companies and protagonists

from different regions because
they will have the opportunity

to learn that talent
and leadership can come
from anywhere in the world.

I believe featuring a family
business that started in Jordan

but then grew to become a
multi-billion-dollar global

pharmaceutical
company also allows

students to appreciate the
talent Jordan and the region

has to offer the world, drawing
parallels with their own family
businesses across the globe.

HBS is a unique
international business school
with a diverse student body.

So it is important for students
to read about companies

in markets beyond North America
and learn about the challenges

and opportunities these
companies face in their growth
journey.

I really liked interacting
with the professors at HBS who

asked very insightful and
thought-provoking questions.

I also liked engaging
with the students

from diverse backgrounds
at the end of class

and getting to hear their
thoughts and perspectives
on the case.

I am so happy and proud that
you were able to tell the Hikma

story to such an
impressive audience

and that our story is now
